Mr. Morgan
page 2
8/9/37
more
to weaken the Japanese through the necessity
of large troup
movements
these several
points than with any idea of driving the
Japanese
take
out.
The
main drive of the
Chinese, in my opinion,
will
place
in North China and all other activities will be
in the
nature of
side shows.
people
claim that the Japanese are
interested
in taking Hopei
province
with a view of tieing it on to
their
Sphere of Influence
in North China.
Others feel that the present
aim of the Japanese is to
extend their control as far South as the
railroad which runs from Haichow near the old mouth of the Yellow
River to Sian on the
West.
My personal
guess is that the present
plan of the Japanese is
to take only Hopei and Charhar,
appetite may be whetted by military success, and almost anything may
follow.
A blockade of ports
along the Coast wo
include
Shanghai
and Canton
and will probably force us to cease operation of the
Shanghai-Canton route, but apart from this "feeder
service" I
can
not see any effect upon the trans-Pacific except that American mails
and passengers will
transportation.
probably have to proceed to Hongkong via
surface
Actually our
trans-Pacific business may enjoy
some -
th ing
of a boom by reason of the disruption of transpotation,
al-
though I fully expect that the Dollar Line, the Canadian Pacific,
and other lines will continue to function as at present with Japanese
supervision of cargo inspection and custons at Shanghai, also
of
course, Japanese censorship of all mail.
We have been extremely busy and I
am dictating this at home
Sunday
morning because there is
little if any opportunity to get any
work done at the office and you probably will not hear from me very
frequently from now on.
Very sincerely,
H. M. Bixby
Vice-President for China
